articles.headline: Georgia Eager to Rebuild Its Defeated Armed Forces
articles.snippet: Georgia’s leaders hope to train the armed forces as if another war with Russia is almost inevitable.
articles.abstract: Georgia’s leaders hope to train the armed forces as if another war with Russia is almost inevitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia  Just weeks after Georgia’s military collapsed in panic in the face of the Russian Army, its leaders hope to rebuild and train its armed forces as if another war with Russia is almost inevitable.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Search Giant Wants a Share of Browser Market
articles.snippet: Google fears that Microsoft could leverage its dominance of the browser market to promote its search business.
articles.abstract: Google fears that Microsoft could leverage its dominance of the browser market to promote its search business.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google’s new browser, Chrome, is named for something it mostly lacks.

articles.headline: Despite Lower Oil Prices, Little Relief for Consumers
articles.snippet: Oil prices are falling but manufacturers have not dropped oil-related price increases they made this year.
articles.abstract: Oil prices are falling but manufacturers have not dropped oil-related price increases they made this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: As oil prices surged this year, manufacturers raised the prices of a lot of products — not just gasoline but lotions, toothpaste, plastics and many more items that use oil as a raw material. But now that oil costs are plunging, other prices are not following them lower — not yet, anyway.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Serious Potential in Google’s Browser
articles.snippet: Google’s minimalist Chrome browser is built for a future that blurs the lines of Web and desktop.
articles.abstract: Google’s minimalist Chrome browser is built for a future that blurs the lines of Web and desktop.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does the world really need another Web browser?

articles.headline: McCain’s Effort to Woo Conservatives Is Paying Off
articles.snippet: The McCain campaign has shored up support among religious conservatives, who viewed him as a nemesis.
articles.abstract: The McCain campaign has shored up support among religious conservatives, who viewed him as a nemesis.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL  Moments after Senator John McCain announced his running mate  Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, an outspoken abortion opponent  his campaign sprang into action to fan flames of enthusiasm among his party’s demoralized conservative supporters.

articles.headline: Palin’s Start in Alaska: Not Politics as Usual
articles.snippet: When Sarah Palin ran for mayor in 1996, Wasilla, Alaska, got its first local lesson in wedge politics.
articles.abstract: When Sarah Palin ran for mayor in 1996, Wasilla, Alaska, got its first local lesson in wedge politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASILLA, Alaska — The world arrived here more than a century ago with the gold rush and later the railroad. Yet one aspect of American life did not come to town until 1996, the year Sarah Palin ran for mayor and Wasilla got its first local lesson in wedge politics.

articles.headline: Wage Gaps for Women Frustrating Germany
articles.snippet: Despite having a woman as head of government, Germany has one of the widest gender wage gaps in Europe.
articles.abstract: Despite having a woman as head of government, Germany has one of the widest gender wage gaps in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Maria Schaad, an ambitious 41-year-old businesswoman, considers herself lucky. After the birth of each of her sons, now 7 and 3, her employer, a major pharmaceutical company, allowed her to work flexible, reduced hours  a perk that is far from a given in Germany.

articles.headline: Abu Dhabi Puts More Cash on the Line in Hollywood
articles.snippet: Abu Dhabi Media, flush with oil cash, is adding to the $1 billion deal it announced with Warner Brothers last year, and is putting another billion in a new movie business.
articles.abstract: Abu Dhabi Media, flush with oil cash, is adding to the $1 billion deal it announced with Warner Brothers last year, and is putting another billion in a new movie business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last September, Abu Dhabi Media Company, an arm of the government in the city-state capitol of the United Arab Emirates, reached a $1 billion deal to make movies and video games with Warner Brothers, the big Hollywood studio owned by Time Warner.

articles.headline: Bush and Lieberman Hail McCain as a Leader
articles.snippet: President Bush’s speech seemed to highlight how eager Senator John McCain is to usher him off the stage.
articles.abstract: President Bush’s speech seemed to highlight how eager Senator John McCain is to usher him off the stage.

articles.headline: American Forces Attack Militants on Pakistani Soil
articles.snippet: Coalition forces opened fire in a village near the Afghan border, killing seven people, the Pakistani military said.
articles.abstract: Coalition forces opened fire in a village near the Afghan border, killing seven people, the Pakistani military said.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Pir Zubair Shah, Eric Schmitt and Jane Perlez.
articles.byline: By Pir Zubair Shah, Eric Schmitt and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: White House Unveils $1 Billion Georgia Aid Plan
articles.snippet: The aid, along with Vice President Dick Cheney’s visit to the region, is sure to inflame tensions with Russia further.
articles.abstract: The aid, along with Vice President Dick Cheney’s visit to the region, is sure to inflame tensions with Russia further.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKU, Azerbaijan  President Bush proposed $1 billion in humanitarian and economic assistance on Wednesday to help rebuild Georgia after its short, disastrous war with Russia last month, but he stopped short of committing the United States to re-equipping its battered military.

articles.headline: Two Brokers Accused of Securities Fraud
articles.snippet: Two former brokers at Credit Suisse have been indicted on fraud and conspiracy charges in connection with the sale of auction-rate securities, federal prosecutors said.
articles.abstract: Two former brokers at Credit Suisse have been indicted on fraud and conspiracy charges in connection with the sale of auction-rate securities, federal prosecutors said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The broker said the securities were as safe as cash. After all, he claimed, the outfit that issued them, Glacier Education Loan, bought student loans guaranteed by the federal government.
